solvingStrategy: 1. Each 3Ã—9 input grid is split into three 3Ã—3 blocks (columns 0-2, 3-5, 6-8). 2. Every training output paints each 3Ã—3 block with a single colour, the same across all three rows, so the task is to identify which solid colour belongs to which 3Ã—3 pattern of 5-pixels. 3. From the four training examples we gathered the following dictionary:   â€¢ pattern â€œall 5s except the centreâ€ â†’ 3   â€¢ pattern â€œonly centre is 5â€         â†’ 4   â€¢ pattern â€œanti-diagonal 5sâ€         â†’ 9   â€¢ pattern â€œbottom row all 5sâ€        â†’ 1   â€¢ pattern â€œtop row all 5sâ€           â†’ 6 4. For the test input the three blocks are:   â€¢ Block1 (cols 0-2): bottom row full of 5s â†’ colour 1   â€¢ Block2 (cols 3-5): anti-diagonal of 5s   â†’ colour 9   â€¢ Block3 (cols 6-8): top row full of 5s    â†’ colour 6 5. Fill each 3Ã—3 block with its colour and copy the same row three times to obtain the 3Ã—9 output.
keySteps: Split every grid into 3Ã—3 column blocks.
Observe that outputs are uniform-colour blocks repeated on all rows.
Build mapping from unique 3Ã—3 5-patterns to colours using all training pairs.
Apply mapping to the three blocks of the test grid and compose final grid.
patternDescription: Map each distinct arrangement of 5s inside a 3Ã—3 block to a unique colour; paint the whole block with that colour.
hints: Algorithm: for each 3-column slice, encode its 3Ã—3 boolean pattern; look it up in the learned dictionary and paint the slice uniformly.
Math view: colour = f(pattern) where f is a one-to-one mapping discovered from the training set; output(i,j) = f(pattern_of_slice(j//3)).
